subject: Geography
note: Concept-level DEVELOPS_SKILL links seeded from v4 teacher simulation (Adeyemi). Maps KS3 Geography concepts to the specific GeographicalSkill sub-types they develop. Adeyemi noted that C007 (Skills) needs splitting into sub-types — these links achieve that functionally by connecting content to specific skill nodes.

links.rationale: Plate tectonics requires using maps to identify plate boundaries, earthquake/volcano distribution patterns, and tectonic hazard zones at global scale.
GIS for plate tectonics: layering earthquake epicentre data, plate boundary locations, and population density to analyse hazard risk zones.
Tectonics data analysis: interpreting seismic data, comparing earthquake magnitude/depth across plate boundaries, statistical analysis of hazard frequency.
Adeyemi: 'Choropleth maps of HDI, GDP per capita are core geography skills.' GIS essential for development — layering economic indicators spatially.
Development data analysis: comparing indicators (GDP, HDI, life expectancy), constructing scatter graphs of development indicators, identifying correlations.
Development enquiry using multiple sources: World Bank data, case study research, comparing development pathways using complex secondary data.
Climate change data analysis: interpreting temperature anomaly graphs, CO2 concentration data, sea level rise trends. Core data interpretation applied to climate.
Climate change enquiry: evaluating evidence from multiple sources (ice cores, satellite data, historical records) to assess causes and impacts.
Adeyemi: 'Population pyramids, migration flow maps, and census data analysis.' Population data requires specialist graphical analysis skills.
Urbanisation fieldwork: investigating land use, environmental quality, traffic counts in contrasting urban areas. Primary data collection in the field.
World regions: using maps and atlases to locate regions, identify spatial patterns of climate, biomes, economic activity at continental/global scales.
World regions: interpreting thematic maps, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to study regional characteristics and compare places.
Place depth study: the core enquiry skill — designing and conducting a geographical investigation using multiple complex sources about a specific place.
Place depth study through fieldwork: collecting primary data in contrasting locations, analysing findings, drawing evidence-based geographical conclusions.
Latitude/longitude and locational knowledge: using maps, atlases and globes to locate places, identify the Equator, Tropics, and time zones.
Locational knowledge requires grid reference skills: four and six-figure references on OS maps to locate specific places in the UK.
Climate zones: geographical enquiry into why different places have different climates. Comparing data from contrasting climate zones.
Climate zones: collecting and presenting weather data through fieldwork — temperature, rainfall, wind. Recording and graphing local weather data.
